Skywalker, whose father was considered the best pilot in the galaxy, flew the
X-wing starfighter that destroyed the Death Star.

Skywalker was acknowledged to be an expert pilot, being the person who was
responsible for destroying the first Death Star and managing to evade Darth
Vader himself (albeit with help from Han Solo).[1] He also managed to destroy
an [Interdictor vessel](/wiki/Interdictor_vessel "Interdictor vessel") on his
own while piloting the _Desert Jewel_ , although he acknowledged that R2-D2
saved him when the astromech droid made the ship jump into hyperspace in the
nick of time.[51] He was also able to pilot a Imperial Lambda-class T-4a
shuttle with relative ease, outmaneuvering an [RZ-1

Star and managing to evade Darth
Vader himself (albeit with help from Han Solo).[1] He also managed to destroy
an [Interdictor vessel](/wiki/Interdictor_vessel "Interdictor vessel") on his
own while piloting the _Desert Jewel_ , although he acknowledged that R2-D2
saved him when the astromech droid made the ship jump into hyperspace in the
nick of time.[51] He was also able to pilot a Imperial Lambda-class T-4a
shuttle with relative ease, outmaneuvering an [RZ-1 A-wing
interceptor](/wiki/RZ-1_A-wing_interceptor "RZ-1 A-wing interceptor") that was
trying to get a lock on him.[196] In fact, Skywalker had a talent for
tinkering and a passion for speed.[237] With no previous experience, Skywalker
was able to pilot a podracer with incredible skill, a feat that an announcer
and Vader acknowledged was impressive.[55] He was considered to be one of the
Alliance's best pilots[121] and gained recognition and fame amongst them for
his skills because he made the shot that destroyed the Death Star.[154] He was
able to pilot a shuttle into Cloud City and avoid the shots from its turret
defenses though he worried he would get them killed.[141] He briefly bested
Vader in a dogfight over Jekara, tricking him into crashing.[160] His piloting
and targeting skills were limited by his fear occasionally, and on one
instance he missed a shot because he had a vision of Vader defeating Solo
during the Battle of Yavin.[154]

He was even able to use a jetpack[174] and was skilled with a speeder, once
using one to take down an Imperial transport.[126] However, he once attempted
to drive a boat and ended up capsizing it.[145] He also could perform
environmental surveys, largely to due farming skills he gained from his time
on Tatooine.[100]

He was a native speaker of [Galactic Basic
Standard](/wiki/Galactic_Basic_Standard "Galactic Basic Standard"),[1] and
although Skywalker could not understand [Shyriiwook](/wiki/Shyriiwook
"Shyriiwook"), he had quickly learned how to read

Standard](/wiki/Galactic_Basic_Standard "Galactic Basic Standard"),[1] and

"Shyriiwook"), he had quickly learned how to read Chewbacca's moods by his
tone and expression before the Battle of Yavin.[6] After decades of missions
with R2, Skywalker was reasonably fluent in droidspeak.[239]

Skywalker was adept in unarmed combat. He demonstrated his skill early on
Cymoon 1 where he defeated a few stormtroopers by kicking and slamming them to
the ground.[12] Shortly afterwards he found himself being attacked by an
entire mob full of alien thugs on Nar Shadaa. Skywalker defeated numerous of
the attackers unarmed before igniting his lightsaber and startling the
rest.[65] He found himself in another similar situation on Horox III, where he
defeated an entire cantina of alien thugs with the help of Aphra and her
Wookiee bounty hunter.[86] Skywalker knocked out the Commander Kanchar, a
hulking cybernetic enhanced man with a single punch after outsmarting him.[99]
He was able to take down a muscled individual who was much larger than him
using only a broom.[121] However, Ellian Zahra was able to knock him down in
an encounter where she was holding back, though he easily dodged her sword
attack.[148]

He was also capable with a blaster,[1] and could also escape ropes tied around
his hands quickly, a skill Doctor Aphra theorized he learned from Han
Solo.[177] It took him time to get used to fighting with a blaster and hand-
to-hand with his prosthetic hand, however.[140] He was capable with a
grappling hook and could use it to both swing[1] and pull items down.[127] He
also knew how to swim.[105]

Skywalker built a new lightsaber after losing his father's weapon.

Luke Skywalker wielded at least three lightsabers during the [Galactic Civil
War](/wiki/Galactic_Civil_War "Galactic Civil War"). The first was his
father's former weapon, that was retrieved and given to him by Obi-Wan
Kenobi.[1] He wielded this weapon for three years before losing it, and the
hand holding it, in a duel against Darth Vader on the cloud city on Bespin.[9]

The second one he obtained shortly after his visit to a Jedi outpost on
Tempes. This saber was a lightsaber pike with only the still functional half
of the lightsaber. Luke eventually fixed the damaged end and continued using
this one to defend himself against foes like Commander Ellian Zahra.[148]
While in No-Space, this lightsaber was crushed and mangled by a killdroid.
R2-D2 attempted to fix it, and while it still ignited, it often dangerously
sputtered and crackled with energy.[175] Dr. Cuata eventually repaired
it.[183]

Eventually, Skywalker built himself a new weapon, with a green blade, that he
used to rescue his friends from Jabba the Hutt and during his final duel with
Darth Vader.[10]

He also briefly utilized one of [Darth Atrius'
lightsabers](/wiki/Darth_Atrius%27_lightsabers

## Behind the scenes

### Portrayal in the Skywalker Saga

#### Original trilogy

For most of his appearances in _[Star Wars saga](/wiki/Star_Wars_saga "Star
Wars saga")_ , Luke Skywalker was portrayed by actor [Mark
Hamill](/wiki/Mark_Hamill "Mark Hamill").[1] For his appearance in [_Star
Wars_ : Episode III _Revenge of the
Sith_](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_III_Revenge_of_the_Sith "Star Wars: Episode
III Revenge of the Sith") , Skywalker was portrayed as a infant by [Aidan
Barton](/wiki/Aidan_Barton "Aidan Barton").[11] In _[Episode IV: A New Hope
Read-Along Storybook and CD](/wiki/Episode_IV:_A_New_Hope_Read-
Along_Storybook_and_CD "Episode IV: A New Hope Read-Along Storybook and CD")_
he was voiced by [Joshua Fardon](/wiki/Joshua_Fardon "Joshua Fardon").[257]

Luke Skywalker's character went through subsequent changes. In George Lucas'
original script, Skywalker was meant to be called Luke Starkiller,[258] at one
point the character was a girl,[259] and Lucas even considered the main
character to be a little person.[260] Luke Skywalker's first name is identical
with George Lucas' high school nickname.[261]

The draft script for the final entry of the original trilogy, what became
[_Star Wars_ : Episode VI _Return of the
Jedi_](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VI_Return_of_the_Jedi "Star Wars: Episode VI
Return of the Jedi"), had Luke fight the Emperor aboard Death Star II with the
assistance of the Force spirits of both his masters, Obi-Wan Kenobi and Yoda.
Skywalker would have been defended by both when Palpatine unleashed his Force
lightning. Kenobi, Yoda, and Anakin Skywalker also returned to having physical
forms in the script, allowing Luke to hug

of the original trilogy, what became
[_Star Wars_ : Episode VI _Return of the
Jedi_](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Episode_VI_Return_of_the_Jedi "Star Wars: Episode VI
Return of the Jedi"), had Luke fight the Emperor aboard Death Star II with the
assistance of the Force spirits of both his masters, Obi-Wan Kenobi and Yoda.
Skywalker would have been defended by both when Palpatine unleashed his Force
lightning. Kenobi, Yoda, and Anakin Skywalker also returned to having physical
forms in the script, allowing Luke to hug his resurrected father.[262]
Skywalker's black costume in _Return of the Jedi_ was intentionally designed
to invoke Vader's also dark outfit.[263]

#### Sequel trilogy

    " _If you look at any classic hero's myth that is actually worth its salt, at the beginning of the hero's journey, like with King Arthur, he pulls the sword from the stone and he's ascendant — he has setbacks but he unites all the kingdoms. But then if you keep reading, when it deals with the hero's life as they get into middle-age and beyond, it always starts to get into darker places. And there's a reason for that: It's because myths are not made to sell action figures; myths are made to reflect the most difficult transitions we go through in life._ "
    ―[Rian Johnson](/wiki/Rian_Johnson "Rian Johnson") on Luke's characterization in _The Last Jedi_[264]

[George Lucas](/wiki/George_Lucas "George Lucas")'s [sequel
trilogy](/wiki/Sequel_trilogy "Sequel trilogy") outline involved a Luke who
had fallen into a dark state of mind, living in self-imposed exile in the
first Jedi Temple. (He is described in [2013](/wiki/2013 "2013") concept art
as "a [Colonel Kurtz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocalypse_Now
"wikipedia:Apocalypse Now") type.")[265] However, Lucas did not give a reason
for Luke's change of attitude.[266] [Michael Arndt](/wiki/Michael_Arndt
"Michael Arndt")'s initial script for _The Force Awakens_ had Luke first
appear halfway through the film, but Arndt came to feel

exile in the
first Jedi Temple. (He is described in [2013](/wiki/2013 "2013") concept art
as "a [Colonel Kurtz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apocalypse_Now
"wikipedia:Apocalypse Now") type.")[265] However, Lucas did not give a reason
for Luke's change of attitude.[266] [Michael Arndt](/wiki/Michael_Arndt
"Michael Arndt")'s initial script for _The Force Awakens_ had Luke first
appear halfway through the film, but Arndt came to feel that Luke's direct
involvement would upstage Rey and the audience would cease caring about her.
Ultimately, he, [J.J. Abrams](/wiki/J.J._Abrams "J.J. Abrams"), and [Lawrence
Kasdan](/wiki/Lawrence_Kasdan "Lawrence Kasdan") agreed Luke would have to
withdraw from the story and become a plot device instead.[267] Hamill still
attended the cast's script reading, thereby concealing Luke's role, and was
assigned to read the stage directions. "It was a way of having [him] be part
of every scene, every moment, not just spiritually or thematically or
narratively, but actually," Abrams said. "Having his voice in it made the read
through a better experience for everyone."[268]

Hamill was initially concerned by how Luke was written in _The Last Jedi_. "I
got into trouble because… I was quoted as saying to Rian [Johnson] that I
fundamentally disagree with everything you decided about Luke, and it was
inartfully [sic] phrased. What I was, was surprised at how he saw Luke. And it
took me a while to get around to his way of thinking, but once I was there it
was a thrilling experience. I hope it will be for the audience too."[269]
Johnson explained: "Honestly, that came out of what I felt was a necessity,
because it came from where he was at the end of _Episode VII, The Force
Awakens_. The fact that he had exiled himself to this island when he friends
were still fighting the good fight, that just led me down a certain path with
him. I couldn't really see any other alternative.";[270] "Knowing that Luke is
a hero, knowing Luke from

get around to his way of thinking, but once I was there it
was a thrilling experience. I hope it will be for the audience too."[269]
Johnson explained: "Honestly, that came out of what I felt was a necessity,
because it came from where he was at the end of _Episode VII, The Force
Awakens_. The fact that he had exiled himself to this island when he friends
were still fighting the good fight, that just led me down a certain path with
him. I couldn't really see any other alternative.";[270] "Knowing that Luke is
a hero, knowing Luke from growing up, I know he must think he's doing the
right thing by taking himself out of the equation. And because he's the last
Jedi, by taking the Jedi out of the equation, by saying, 'I'm taking the Jedi
out of this fight,' he must think that's the best thing for the galaxy."[271]
Hamill agreed that an old, comfortable Luke would have been too reminiscent of
Obi-Wan, but his issue was that "'Jedis [sic] don't give up.'" Johnson added
the back-and-forth to get Luke's character to make sense helped "made me
really dig in and justify the choices I had made to bring Luke to where he was
at. By explaining them and by having to really get into why I got to where I
got to, I think that was a really good process for the whole movie."[272] To
get into character, Hamill thought of the real life hopes and disappointments
of [his generation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baby_boomers "wikipedia:Baby
boomers").[273]

Johnson deemed it best to conclude Luke's _Last Jedi_ arc with him dying
partly because, "honestly, thinking about the number of characters we have on
our plate going into the next movie [...] it just vaguely seemed good to me
that putting Luke in another realm could open possibilities for his possible
involvement in the next one. As opposed to him just being another character
that had to be juggled into the plot, if that makes sense." He was unconcerned
that the audience might feel unable to cope with Luke's death so soon after
Han's murder in _The Force Awakens_ , as Luke's passing was victorious and
peaceful, not a violent defeat.[274] Hamill was particularly not keen

thinking about the number of characters we have on
our plate going into the next movie [...] it just vaguely seemed good to me
that putting Luke in another realm could open possibilities for his possible
involvement in the next one. As opposed to him just being another character
that had to be juggled into the plot, if that makes sense." He was unconcerned
that the audience might feel unable to cope with Luke's death so soon after
Han's murder in _The Force Awakens_ , as Luke's passing was victorious and
peaceful, not a violent defeat.[274] Hamill was particularly not keen on Luke
dying, feeling he had to return a triumphant hero, but Johnson argued that "if
Skywalker just came back like he did in the original trilogy, an optimistic
fighter, he's just an older version of Rey. And Johnson needed someone to
bounce up against Rey."[275] Hamill said his primary lesson from the
experience was how, "At times, I'd say to Rian, 'We gotta think of what the
audience wants,' "And he would say, 'No, we've gotta think of what we
want.'"[276]

Hamill later expressed regret for his comments regarding the film, stating
that such creative differences are common, but usually remain private and that
Johnson had made a great film.[277] He later disclosed he had similarly
disputed the way the character was written in _Return of the Jedi_ , revealing
"I read [the script for] Jedi and thought, 'Wait a sec! I thought I was
heading toward the struggle of heading to the Dark Side. I'm in black. I have
a glove. I see a trend here.'"[278]

_The Rise of Skywalker_ reveals Luke and Leia knew about Rey's ancestry,
despite the revelation not having been conceived during production of the
previous two films. Co-writer [Chris Terrio](/wiki/Chris_Terrio "Chris
Terrio") said, "This one I have to leave to the imagination of the viewer.
But, I don't think it would be wrong to assume that Luke's Force Ghost would
seek out his Force-sensitive, Jedi-trained sister."[279]

### Portrayal in _The Mandalorian_

In _[The Mandalorian](/wiki/The_Mandalorian "The Mandalorian")_ 's "[Chapter
16: The Rescue](/wiki/Chapter_16:_The_Rescue "Chapter 16: The Rescue")," [Max
Lloyd Jones](/wiki/Max_Lloyd_Jones "Max Lloyd Jones") physically portrayed the
character, with [Matt Rugetti](/wiki/Matt_Rugetti "Matt Rugetti") serving as a
stunt double.[16] Both Hamill and Jones were filmed--Jones with all of the
cast, and Hamill when most of the cast and crew were filming outside of the
studio. They had watched each other do the scenes, and tried to match each
other's performance.
[Lola's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lola_Visual_Effects "wikipedia:Lola
Visual Effects") digital [de-aging](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De-
aging_in_film "wikipedia:De-aging in film") was used to make the character
look like young Luke Skywalker, and the voice was completely synthesised using
an application called Respeecher. To prevent this appearance from leaking, the
scripts had [Plo Koon](/wiki/Plo_Koon "Plo Koon") written instead of Luke
Skywalker, and a concept art of Plo Koon destroying dark troopers was
created.[280]

trooper](/wiki/Clone_trooper "Clone trooper") [Cody](/wiki/Cody "Cody") in
charge of Luke Skywalker, which was meant to be a side plot that the film
would cut away to. Cody was planned as a way to show how disconnected Kenobi

from the Empire. Tao, the lead refugee woman, took Kenobi to a sacred shrine
and instructed the Jedi Master to let their goddess speak to him. Kenobi was
then on Mustafar and was attacked by Luke Skywalker played by a de-aged Mark
Hamill. Skywalker almost killed Kenobi, but he snapped out the vision and
realized that putting his guilt on Skywalker would turn him to the dark side.
Beattie was excited to be part of the first _[Star Wars](/wiki/Star_Wars "Star
Wars")_ project to bring back

### _Trials on Tatooine_

    " _Good luck with whatever Luke has you doing down here._ "
    ―Han Solo to Skywalker's student about Luke[287]

In the cinematic virtual-reality game, _[Star Wars: Trials on
Tatooine](/wiki/Star_Wars:_Trials_on_Tatooine "Star Wars: Trials on
Tatooine")_ , After Skywalker had many journeys to the distant corners of the
galaxy, uncovering secrets about the legacy of the Jedi, he felt ready to
create a new Jedi Order. He took on a [padawan
learner](/wiki/Unidentified_hopeful_Padawan "Unidentified hopeful Padawan"),
who was hoping to join the Jedi Order, and sent the Padawan on a
[mission](/wiki/Mission_to_Tatooine_\(Hopeful_Padawan\) "Mission to Tatooine
\(Hopeful Padawan\)") to Tatooine to await a delivery from Han Solo. The
_Millennium Falcon_ landed, and R2-D2 handed the Padawan a lightsaber.
However, remnants of the Galactic Empire began an operation to attack the
Padawan.[287]
